NAEB Headquarters
O U Gregory Hall
Urbana, Illinois
TOs Burton Paulu and Permanent Flnaneing Committee
FROM* Harold
DATE: March 21, 1957
As directed by the Permanent financing Committee herewith information pertaining to the
services now performed by the Headquarters staff and those which might still be performed
if the Headquarters finds it necessary to operate under the minimum budget set forth in
Miles9 letter of November 21, 1956 to then-President Prank Schooley.
PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS: This analysis does NOT include any of those projects fi¬
nanced by the Ford foundation (Engineering Service, Placement Service, Management Consul¬
tant, Consultant Teams, professional advancement activities, etc*) since their continuance
is not dependent upon the funds to be raised for the Headquarters operation. However, it
would be well to keep in mind that having the Engineering and Placement Services at Head¬
quarters has resulted in some saving of secretarial and office expense in that these two
services have provided some personnel for help in handling many more or less routine
matters. The feeling has been that a certain use of Engineering and Placement services
and supplies is justified in view of the fact that these services are provided with office
^ace, editorial help, etc. which they would not otherwise have enjoyed.
Neither does this analysis take into consideration the Network operation vhioh is deemed
to be self-supporting. However, it must be kept in mind that the Executive Director and
the Associate Director devote considerable time to the affairs of the Network. In addition,
the Headquarters secretarial staff does quite a bit of work for the Network. This of course
is important in view of the fact that none of the Network income is diverted to the Head¬
quarters operation even though, as a matter of fact, it is doubtful that the Network could
survive as a separate entity. In connection with this, it should be pointed out that the
Network income is not sufficient to allow for satisfactory amortisation of electronic
equipment. Also, the office furniture used by the Netowrk has largely been purchased by
the Headquarters or has been loaned by the University of Illinois {School of Journalism and
Communications. It should be realized, therefore, that although the Network operation is
not herein considered, if the proposed minimum budget becomes operative, either the Head¬
quarters services to the Network must be reduced (thus reducing the present efficiency of
the Network) or the other services of the Headquarters hereinafter discussed would have
to be reduced still further to permit the reduced Headquarters staff to continue to serve
the Network at the present level.
ANALYSIS OF TOE PRESENT AND PROPOSED MINIMUM BUDGETS:
Headquarters staff: Tie proposed budget would eliminate the Associate Director and one
secretarial person, plus & $1,000 annual allowance for miscellaneous, part-time secretarial
help, thus cutting the present staff by more than 5056, and leaving only the Executive
Director and one secretary.
